document_title: Dilated cardiomyopathy: Causes, signs, treatment and prevention
subsection_content:
Dilated cardiomyopathy is diagnosed based on medical history, clinical examination, heart auscultation and other paraclinical tests. During the cardiovascular examination and medical history, if signs of myocardial dilatation are detected, the doctor will suggest you perform paraclinical tests such as blood tests, electrocardiogram (ECG), and X-rays. -chest ray, echocardiogram, Holter electrocardiogram, cardiac catheterization or CT scan of the heart and coronary arteries, cardiac MRI... to find the cause of myocardial dilation. (4)
Sometimes, a myocardial biopsy (small tissue samples taken from the heart and examined under a microscope) may be performed to determine the cause of the disease.
“Family members with a history of familial idiopathic dilated cardiomyopathy should be screened for the disease with echocardiography and genetic testing. This helps identify abnormal genes, thereby detecting diseases early for timely intervention," emphasized MSc. Huynh Thanh Kieu.
Electrocardiography (ECG) helps detect cardiomyopathy early
